President Donald Trump praised Gretchen Whitmer in a White House meeting on Wednesday, echoing a bipartisan message the Michigan governor delivered during an earlier speech in Washington, D.C.

Trump spoke positively of Whitmer‚Äôs leadership, and even brought her with him to the Oval Office while he signed a number of unrelated executive orders.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre honored to have Gretchen Whitmer from Michigan, the great State of Michigan, and she‚Äôs been, she‚Äôs really done an excellent job, a very good person,‚Äù Trump said.

Whitmer‚Äôs spokesperson said she was ‚Äúsurprised she was brought into the Oval Office‚Äù for Trump‚Äôs press conference ‚Äúwithout any notice.‚Äù

Whitmer has emerged as one of the key Democratic contenders to run for president in 2028. Even though the governor insists she is not setting herself up for the White House, Whitmer will come up on her term limit in 2026 and has successfully rallied voters in a state that Trump has carried twice.

Among the directives Trump signed, heopened investigationsinto two of his first-term aides: former Department of Homeland Secretary official Miles Taylor and former Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency Director Chris Krebs. The president accused Taylor of fraud, Krebs of treason, then stripped both their security clearances, repeating false claims that the 2020 election was stolen.

‚ÄúHer presence is not an endorsement of the actions taken or statements made at that event,‚Äù Whitmer‚Äôs spokesperson said.

Whitmer‚Äôs approach with Trump on Wednesday contrasted the staunch criticism that has united much of the Democratic Party‚Äôs platform, specifically around tariffs. Other Democratic governors that have been floated as 2028 hopefuls, like Colorado Gov. Jared Polis or Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker, have denounced the tariffs as a tax on average American families.

Whitmer struck a different tone in her speech, emphasizing their common ground related to building up manufacturing jobs in Michigan.

‚ÄúI understand the motivation behind the tariffs, and here‚Äôs where President Trump and I do agree. We do need to make more stuff in America,‚Äù Whitmer said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not against tariffs outright, but they are a blunt tool. You can‚Äôt just bust out the tariff hammer to swing at every problem without a clearly defined end goal.‚Äù

She pushed for tariff exemptions for the auto and energy industries, which are crucial to Michigan‚Äôs economy. Trump‚Äôs 90-day pause on tariffs will not include those levied on auto imports.

The conciliatory relationship is a departure from Trump‚Äôs first term, where he and Whitmer repeatedly butted heads ‚Äî especially on the response to the COVID-19 pandemic, whenTrump called her inept. He also referred to her as ‚Äúthe woman from Michigan,‚Äù which Whitmerreclaimed in a post on X.

As for Trump‚Äôs second term, Whitmer signaled that she‚Äôs open to working with the president to help her state.

For the second time in a month, Michigan Democratic Gov. Gretchen Whitmer was scheduled to meet with second-term Republican President Donald Trump on Wednesday as the state continues to confront tariff and manufacturing issues.

Before that meeting, Whitmer delivered a speech near the White House to lay out her long-term ideas to grow American manufacturing and build national defense.

Earlier this year, Whitmer was a vocal critic of Trump‚Äôs tariff plans but has been relatively silent since broad taxes on goods entering the country were enacted last week.

In her speech, she pushed for targeted tariffs rather than the broad measures Trump introduced last week, which sent world financial markets diving.

She called the tariffs the largest tax increase in 60 years, costing families an average of $1,900 a year and damaging 401(k)s and IRAs, forcing delayed retirements.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre already seeing the impacts,‚Äù Whitmer said. "Auto companies are stockpiling parts and laying off workers. Suppliers are facing higher costs and delaying expansions. Dealerships will be forced to raise prices by up to $15,000 amid slowing sales. And since every auto job supports three others in the community, the impact will be felt by countless small businesses across Michigan, too."

However, she does agree with Trump on increasing American manufacturing of ships, steel, cars and chips, and said America needs fair trade.

‚ÄúNo state has lived through the consequences of offshoring and outsourcing more than Michigan," Whitmer said. "We know losing a factory doesn‚Äôt just mean losing jobs. Losing people means losing resources. It means fewer police officers and underfunded schools. It means less housing built and fewer roads fixed. It‚Äôs a loss of purpose and identity.

‚ÄúSo, while I share the president‚Äôs goal of bringing good-paying, middle-class manufacturing jobs back home, it‚Äôs got to be done right.‚Äù

Whitmer‚Äôs plan involves carving out the auto and energy industries and placing tariffs on technology officials want to produce in the United States. She also proposed investing new revenue created by tariffs into American businesses and workers.

‚ÄúAs I‚Äôve said before, I‚Äôm not against tariffs outright, but they are a blunt tool," Whitmer said. "You can‚Äôt just bust out the tariff hammer to swing at every problem without a clearly defined end goal.
